elements.content: The homoleptic complexes [Ph4P]2{Co[N(CN)2]4} and [Ph4P]{M[N(CN)2]3} [M = Co, Mn] have been structurally as well as magnetically characterized. The complexes containing {M[N(CN)2]4}2- form 1-D chains, which are bridged via a common dicyanamide ligand in {M[N(CN)2]3}- to form a 2-D structure. The five-atom [NCNCN]- bridging ligands lead to weak magnetic coupling along a chain. The six [NCNCN]- ligands lead to a 4T1g ground state for Co(II) which has an unquenched spin−orbit coupling that is reflected in the magnetic properties. Long-range magnetic ordering was not observed in any of these materials.
elements.clean_text: The homoleptic complexes [Ph4P]2{Co[N(CN)2]4} and [Ph4P]{M[N(CN)2]3} [M = Co, Mn] have been structurally as well as magnetically characterized. The complexes containing {M[N(CN)2]4}2- form 1-D chains, which are bridged via a common dicyanamide ligand in {M[N(CN)2]3}- to form a 2-D structure. The five-atom [NCNCN]- bridging ligands lead to weak magnetic coupling along a chain. The six [NCNCN]- ligands lead to a 4T1g ground state for Co(II) which has an unquenched spin-orbit coupling that is reflected in the magnetic properties. Long-range magnetic ordering was not observed in any of these materials.

The complexes containing {M[N(CN)2]4}2- form 1-D chains, which are bridged via a common dicyanamide ligand in {M[N(CN)2]3}- to form a 2-D structure. The five-atom [NCNCN]- bridging ligands lead to weak magnetic coupling along a chain. The six [NCNCN]- ligands lead to a 4T1g ground state for Co(II) which has an unquenched spin−orbit coupling that is reflected in the magnetic properties.

The complexes containing {M[N(CN)2]4}2- form 1-D chains, which are bridged via a common dicyanamide ligand in {M[N(CN)2]3}- to form a 2-D structure. The five-atom [NCNCN]- bridging ligands lead to weak magnetic coupling along a chain. The six [NCNCN]- ligands lead to a 4T1g ground state for Co(II) which has an unquenched spin-orbit coupling that is reflected in the magnetic properties.

elements.content:
Dedicated to Alan L. Balch on the occasion of his 60th birthday.

Introduction

The magnetic behavior of homo- and heteroleptic complexes with the dicyanamide ligand, [N(CN)2]-, has received considerable recent attention. Homoleptic complexes with divalent transition metals, MII[N(CN)2]2 (M = Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni3-5), magnetically order as ferro- or weak antiferromagnets with T c ≤ 47 K. In contrast, heteroleptic complexes have yet to be reported to magnetically order. In the homoleptic compounds, [N(CN)2]- is tricoordinate, bridging three different metal sites, while in the heteroleptic compounds, dicyanamide bridges two metal sites exclusively via the nitriles. To further establish the magnetic structure−function relationship as well as identify new magnetically ordered materials, we investigated three new homoleptic compounds, [Ph4P]2{Co[N(CN)2]4} (1) and [Ph4P]{M[N(CN)2]3} [M = Co (2), Mn (3)].
elements.clean_text:
Dedicated to Alan L. Balch on the occasion of his 60th birthday.

Introduction

The magnetic behavior of homo- and heteroleptic complexes with the dicyanamide ligand, [N(CN)2]-, has received considerable recent attention. Homoleptic complexes with divalent transition metals, MII[N(CN)2]2 (M = Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni3-5), magnetically order as ferro- or weak antiferromagnets with T c ≤ 47 K. In contrast, heteroleptic complexes have yet to be reported to magnetically order. In the homoleptic compounds, [N(CN)2]- is tricoordinate, bridging three different metal sites, while in the heteroleptic compounds, dicyanamide bridges two metal sites exclusively via the nitriles. To further establish the magnetic structure-function relationship as well as identify new magnetically ordered materials, we investigated three new homoleptic compounds, [Ph4P]2{Co[N(CN)2]4} (1) and [Ph4P]{M[N(CN)2]3} [M = Co (2), Mn (3)].

elements.content: The chemistry of dicyanamide as a ligand has been explored for many years. Köhler and co-workers published a series of papers in the 1960s and 1970s describing transition metal dicyanamide complexes. They reported the preparation of several cobalt dicyanamde complexes including (Ph3MeAs){Co[N(CN)2]3}. We have utilized the tetraphenylphosphonium salt of dicyanamide as a starting material to prepare 1−3.
elements.clean_text: The chemistry of dicyanamide as a ligand has been explored for many years. Köhler and co-workers published a series of papers in the 1960s and 1970s describing transition metal dicyanamide complexes. They reported the preparation of several cobalt dicyanamde complexes including (Ph3MeAs){Co[N(CN)2]3}. We have utilized the tetraphenylphosphonium salt of dicyanamide as a starting material to prepare 1-3.

elements.content: Co(NO3)2·6H2O and MnCl2·4H2O (Baker) were used as purchased. [Ph4P][N(CN)2] and K[N(CN)2] were synthesized by metathesis from Ag[N(CN)2]. Infrared spectra were recorded on a Bio-Rad FTS-40 FT-IR spectrometer with samples prepared as Nujol mulls. Absorption spectra were recorded on a Hewlett-Packard 8452A diode-array spectrophotometer. Magnetic measurements were taken on a Quantum Design MPMS-5T magnetometer as previously described.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O and MnCl2⋅4H2O (Baker) were used as purchased. [Ph4P][N(CN)2] and K[N(CN)2] were synthesized by metathesis from Ag[N(CN)2]. Infrared spectra were recorded on a Bio-Rad FTS-40 FT-IR spectrometer with samples prepared as Nujol mulls. Absorption spectra were recorded on a Hewlett-Packard 8452A diode-array spectrophotometer. Magnetic measurements were taken on a Quantum Design MPMS-5T magnetometer as previously described.

elements.content: [Ph 4 P] 2 {Co[N(CN) 2 ] 4 } (1). A solution of 0.35 g (1.2 mmol) of Co(NO3)2·6H2O dissolved in 30 mL of acetone was added to a stirred solution of 0.25 g (2.4 mmol) of K[N(CN)2] and 0.97 g (2.4 mmol) of (Ph4P)[N(CN)2] in 120 mL of acetone. The resulting dark blue solution was stirred for 5 min and then filtered. The filtrate was reduced to 30 mL, and ether diffusion produced a mixture of white and pink needles. The mixture was washed with 95% ethanol to remove the white crystals and produce 180 mg (15%) of homogeneous pink needles.
elements.clean_text: [Ph  4  P]  2  {Co[N(CN)  2  ]  4  } (1). A solution of 0.35 g (1.2 mmol) of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O dissolved in 30 mL of acetone was added to a stirred solution of 0.25 g (2.4 mmol) of K[N(CN)2] and 0.97 g (2.4 mmol) of (Ph4P)[N(CN)2] in 120 mL of acetone. The resulting dark blue solution was stirred for 5 min and then filtered. The filtrate was reduced to 30 mL, and ether diffusion produced a mixture of white and pink needles. The mixture was washed with 95% ethanol to remove the white crystals and produce 180 mg (15%) of homogeneous pink needles.

elements.content: [Ph 4 P]{Co[N(CN) 2 ] 3 } (2). A solution of 0.30 g (1.0 mmol) of Co(NO3)2·6H2O dissolved in 30 mL of acetone was added to a stirred solution of 0.22 g (2.0 mmol) of K[N(CN)2] and 0.42 g (1.0 mmol) of (Ph4P)[N(CN)2] in 120 mL of acetone. The resulting dark blue solution was stirred for 1 h and then filtered. The filtrate was reduced to 20 mL, and ether diffusion produced 75 mg (10%) of pink block crystals.
elements.clean_text: [Ph  4  P]{Co[N(CN)  2  ]  3  } (2). A solution of 0.30 g (1.0 mmol) of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O dissolved in 30 mL of acetone was added to a stirred solution of 0.22 g (2.0 mmol) of K[N(CN)2] and 0.42 g (1.0 mmol) of (Ph4P)[N(CN)2] in 120 mL of acetone. The resulting dark blue solution was stirred for 1 h and then filtered. The filtrate was reduced to 20 mL, and ether diffusion produced 75 mg (10%) of pink block crystals.

elements.content: [Ph 4 P]{Mn[N(CN) 2 ] 3 } (3). A solution of 0.186 g (0.94 mmol) of MnCl2·4H2O in 10 mL of ethanol was slowly added to a solution of 0.800 g (1.97 mmol) of [Ph4P][N(CN)2] in 10 mL of CH2Cl2 to give a colorless solution. The reaction mixture was allowed to slowly evaporate at room temperature for 3 days, at which time large colorless blocks of [Ph4P]{Mn[N(CN)2]3} had grown. The crystals were collected via vacuum filtration and air-dried to give 0.249 g (45%) of colorless block crystals.
elements.clean_text: [Ph  4  P]{Mn[N(CN)  2  ]  3  } (3). A solution of 0.186 g (0.94 mmol) of MnCl2⋅4H2O in 10 mL of ethanol was slowly added to a solution of 0.800 g (1.97 mmol) of [Ph4P][N(CN)2] in 10 mL of CH2Cl2 to give a colorless solution. The reaction mixture was allowed to slowly evaporate  at room temperature for 3 days, at which time large colorless blocks of [Ph4P]{Mn[N(CN)2]3} had grown. The crystals were collected via vacuum filtration and air-dried to give 0.249 g (45%) of colorless block crystals.

elements.content: The known homoleptic compounds, MII[N(CN)2]2, are prepared from aqueous solution. In order to achieve different products, [Ph4P][N(CN)2] was used as a source of dicyanamide in the acetone (CoII) and CH2Cl2/ethanol (MnII). The products [Ph4P]2{Co[N(CN)2]4} (1) and [Ph4P]{Co[N(CN)2]3} (2) were produced as large pink crystals by ether diffusion, and [Ph4P]{Mn[N(CN)2]3} (3) was produced by solvent evaporation as large, colorless crystals. Related compounds have been prepared by Köhler and co-workers in their investigations of dicyanamide complexes. They reported a number of homoleptic complexes including {M[N(CN)2]4}2- (M = Pd, Pt)10 and {Ni[N(CN)2]3}-, as monomeric species with terminal dicyanamide ligands. They also reported several cobalt compounds including [Ph3MeAs]{Co[N(CN)2]3} (4) and [Ph3MeAs]2{Co[N(CN)2]4}8 (5) as octahedral compounds in the solid state and tetrahedral in solution; however, neither their structure nor their temperature-dependent magnetic properties were reported, and data supporting these formulations were limited. Compounds 1 and 2 have properties similar, but not identical, to those of 4 and 5.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The known homoleptic compounds, MII[N(CN)2]2, are prepared from aqueous solution. In order to achieve different products, [Ph4P][N(CN)2] was used as a source of dicyanamide in the acetone (CoII) and CH2Cl2/ethanol (MnII). The products [Ph4P]2{Co[N(CN)2]4} (1) and [Ph4P]{Co[N(CN)2]3} (2) were produced as large pink crystals by ether diffusion, and [Ph4P]{Mn[N(CN)2]3} (3) was produced by solvent evaporation as large, colorless crystals. Related compounds have been prepared by Köhler and co-workers in their investigations of dicyanamide complexes. They reported a number of homoleptic complexes including {M[N(CN)2]4}2- (M = Pd, Pt)10 and {Ni[N(CN)2]3}-, as monomeric species with terminal dicyanamide ligands. They also reported several cobalt compounds including [Ph3MeAs]{Co[N(CN)2]3} (4) and [Ph3MeAs]2{Co[N(CN)2]4}8 (5) as octahedral compounds in the solid state and tetrahedral in solution; however, neither their structure nor their temperature-dependent magnetic properties were reported, and data supporting these formulations were limited. Compounds 1 and 2 have properties similar, but not identical, to those of 4 and 5.

elements.content: The structures of 1−3 have been determined from single-crystal X-ray analyses; crystallographic data are summarized in Table . In each case the MII (M = Mn, Co) is hexacoordinate and surrounded by six dicyanamide ligands nitrile-bound to M, with two pair of dicyanamides bridging adjacent M's, i.e., 6 a . These 6 a M−N distances average 2.163 and 2.116 Å for 1 and 2, respectively, and average 2.113 Å for 3. Each M is also coordinated to two additional dicyanamides, 6 b , with 6 b M−N distances of 2.083, 2.157, 2.277 Å for 1, 2, and 3, respectively. These values are consistent with previously reported M−N distances, e.g., 2.101 and 2.161 Å for Co[N(CN)2]2.
elements.clean_text: The structures of 1-3 have been determined from single-crystal X-ray analyses; crystallographic data are summarized in Table . In each case the MII (M = Mn, Co) is hexacoordinate and surrounded by six dicyanamide ligands nitrile-bound to M, with two pair of dicyanamides bridging adjacent M's, i.e., 6  a . These 6  a  M-N distances average 2.163 and 2.116 Å for 1 and 2, respectively, and average 2.113 Å for 3. Each M is also coordinated to two additional dicyanamides, 6  b , with 6  b  M-N distances of 2.083, 2.157, 2.277 Å for 1, 2, and 3, respectively. These values are consistent with previously reported M-N distances, e.g., 2.101 and 2.161 Å for Co[N(CN)2]2.

Crystallographic Data for [Ph4P]2{Co[N(CN)2]4}, 1, and [Ph4P]{M[N(CN)2]3}, M = Co, 2, Mn, 3

1 2 3 chem formula C56H40CoN12P2 C30H20CoN9P C30H20MnN9P fw (g mol-1) 1001.87 596.45 592.46 space group C2/c P2/n P2/n a (Å) 23.3789(10) 13.4354(10) 13.3903(6) b (Å) 7.5684(3) 7.4426(5) 7.5745(3) c (Å) 28.3778(12) 14.1556(10) 14.3935(6) β (deg) 105.6210(10) 101.0870(10) 99.663(2) V (Å3) 4835.7(3) 1389.06(17) 1439.15(10) Z 4 2 2 T (K) 173(2) 173(2) 295(2) λ (Å) 0.71073 0.71073 0.71073 D calc (g cm-3) 1.376 1.426 1.367 μ (cm-1) 47.4 71.3 55.1 R a 0.0323 0.0533 0.0344 R w  b 0.0817 0.0986 0.0894

a   R = ∑[|F o| − |F c|]/∑|F o|. b   R w = [∑w[|F o| − |F c|]2/∑w|F o|2]1/2.

Compound 1 forms a 1-D chain with the two terminal dicyanamide ligands per Co, 6 b , Figure . The terminal [N(CN)2]- ligands of each chain interdigitate with those from adjacent chains. In contrast, 2 and 3 are isostructural and have a 2-D network, as typified by 2, Figure . For 2 and 3 the terminal [N(CN)2]- ligands on one chain bridge to an adjacent chain, hence the stoichiometry for 1 is {CoII[N(CN)2]4}2-, while it is {MII[N(CN)2]3}- for 2 and 3. In each case the [Ph4P]+ cations lie between the chains or sheets.

The terminal [N(CN)2]- ligands of each chain interdigitate with those from adjacent chains. In contrast, 2 and 3 are isostructural and have a 2-D network, as typified by 2, Figure . For 2 and 3 the terminal [N(CN)2]- ligands on one chain bridge to an adjacent chain, hence the stoichiometry for 1 is {CoII[N(CN)2]4}2-, while it is {MII[N(CN)2]3}- for 2 and 3. In each case the [Ph4P]+ cations lie between the chains or sheets.

elements.content: Chain (1-D) network structure of [Ph4P]2{Co[N(CN)2]4}, 1. The cations have been omitted for clarity.

elements.content: Layered (2-D) network structure of [Ph4P]{Co[N(CN)2]3}, 2 (3 is isomorphous). The cations have been omitted for clarity.

elements.content: Compound 1 appears to be a precursor for the formation of the sheets in compound 2. The loss of [Ph4P][N(CN)2] per Co would result in the bridging of the chains in 1 to form the sheets of 2. This is observed as recrystallization of 1 from acetone/ ether produces the pink block crystals of 2 as confirmed by unit cell analysis and infrared spectroscopy.
elements.clean_text: Compound 1 appears to be a precursor for the formation of the sheets in compound 2. The loss of [Ph4P][N(CN)2] per Co would result in the bridging of the chains in 1 to form the sheets of 2. This is observed as recrystallization of 1 from acetone/ ether produces the pink block crystals of 2 as confirmed by unit cell analysis and infrared spectroscopy.

elements.content: Linear chain structured 1 has IR νCN stretching absorptions at 2277 (s), 2229 (w), 2222 (m), and 2162 (vs) cm-1. In contrast, 2 has νCN absorptions at 2291 (s), 2246 (m), 2232 (w), and 2175 (vs) cm-1, and 3 has similar absorptions at 2292 (s), 2240 (m), 2224 (w), 2177 (vs) and 2165 (vs) cm-1. Unfortunately, there are no assignments for these absorptions, and absorptions of 2 do not correspond to 2259, 2246, 2200, and 2170 cm-1 reported for [Ph3MeAs]{Co[N(CN)2]3} (4), suggesting that it may be of different stoichiometry.
elements.clean_text: Linear chain structured 1 has IR νCN stretching absorptions at 2277 (s), 2229 (w), 2222 (m), and 2162 (vs) cm-1. In contrast, 2 has νCN absorptions at 2291 (s), 2246 (m), 2232 (w), and 2175 (vs) cm-1, and 3 has similar absorptions at 2292 (s), 2240 (m), 2224 (w), 2177 (vs) and 2165 (vs) cm-1. Unfortunately, there are no assignments for these absorptions, and absorptions of 2 do not correspond to 2259, 2246, 2200, and 2170 cm-1 reported for [Ph3MeAs]{Co[N(CN)2]3} (4), suggesting that it may be of different stoichiometry.

elements.content: The pink crystals of 2 are partially soluble in both dichloromethane and acetone. Addition of 5 equiv of [Ph4P][N(CN)2] to the crystals in acetone leads to complete dissolution of 2, forming a dark blue solution. The UV−visible absorption spectrum of the resultant solution has two absorptions at 16 400 cm-1 (ε = 1000 cm-1 M-1) and 16 700 cm-1 (1020 cm-1 M-1) and a shoulder at 17 500 cm-1 (ε = 700 cm-1 M-1). The peak positions are the same in neat acetone and dichloromethane (when some solid remains undissolved), indicating that the soluble species is the same in either solvent. The peaks correspond to the absorptions for tetrahedral CoII, which has features between 14 000 and 17 000 cm-1 assigned to the 4A2(F) → 4T1(F) transition (octahedral CoII has peaks at 19 600 and 21 600 cm-1 assigned to the 4T1g(F) → 4A2g(F) and 4T1g(F) → 4T1g(P) transitions, respectively). This also corresponds to the reflectance spectrum obtained for β-Co[N(CN)2]2, a network structure proposed to have tetrahedral symmetry. Therefore, it seems likely that in solution, and only in solution, tetrahedral {Co[N(CN)2]4}2- forms. It is proposed to form via the equilibrium in eq 1 in an excess of dicyanamide.
elements.clean_text: The pink crystals of 2 are partially soluble in both dichloromethane and acetone. Addition of 5 equiv of [Ph4P][N(CN)2] to the crystals in acetone leads to complete dissolution of 2, forming a dark blue solution. The UV-visible absorption spectrum of the resultant solution has two absorptions at 16400 cm-1 (ε = 1000 cm-1 M-1) and 16700 cm-1 (1020 cm-1 M-1) and a shoulder at 17500 cm-1 (ε = 700 cm-1 M-1). The peak positions are the same in neat acetone and dichloromethane (when some solid remains undissolved), indicating that the soluble species is the same in either solvent. The peaks correspond to the absorptions for tetrahedral CoII, which has features between 14000 and 17000 cm-1 assigned to the 4A2(F) → 4T1(F) transition (octahedral CoII has peaks at 19600 and 21600 cm-1 assigned to the 4T1g(F) → 4A2g(F) and 4T1g(F) → 4T1g(P) transitions, respectively). This also corresponds to the reflectance spectrum obtained for β-Co[N(CN)2]2, a network structure proposed to have tetrahedral symmetry. Therefore, it seems likely that in solution, and only in solution, tetrahedral {Co[N(CN)2]4}2- forms. It is proposed to form via the equilibrium in eq 1 in an excess of dicyanamide.

elements.content: The temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibilities of 1−3 was measured between 2 and 300 K. 1−3 have room temperature moments of 5.14, 5.14, and 5.85 μB, respectively. The value for 3 is as expected for uncoupled spin-only S = 5/2 MnII. In contrast, the moments for 1 and 2 substantially exceed the spin-only value of 3.84 μB expected for high-spin CoII.
elements.clean_text: The temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibilities of 1-3 was measured between 2 and 300 K. 1-3 have room temperature moments of 5.14, 5.14, and 5.85 μB, respectively. The value for 3 is as expected for uncoupled spin-only S = 5/2 MnII. In contrast, the moments for 1 and 2 substantially exceed the spin-only value of 3.84 μB expected for high-spin CoII.

elements.content: The temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility, χ, of [Ph4P]2{Co[N(CN)2]4}, 1, and [Ph4P]{Co[N(CN)2]3}, 2, cannot be fit to the Curie−Weiss expression, χ ∝ [T − θ]-1, due to the curvature of μ(T), Figure . High-spin octahedral CoII has a 4T1g ground state and, as a consequence, exhibits unquenched spin−orbit coupling in addition to zero-field splitting, which dominates at low temperature. Unfortunately, no expression accounts for both factors simultaneously. Therefore, the data for 2 were fit with eq 2 (with x = λ/k B T) for spin−orbit coupling, λ, of CoII, which dominates above 50 K (Figure ). The best fit is obtained with values of A = 1.5, k = 1.0, λ = −170 cm-1, and ν = 3, where A is a crystal field parameter (A = 1.5 is weak-field limit), k represents electron delocalization (k = 1.0 is minimal), λ is the spin−orbit coupling constant (λ = −176 cm-1 is the free-ion value), and ν describes the distorted geometrical configurations (ν is proportional to 1/λ). Thus, the fit suggests cobalt ions with slightly distorted octahedral geometry, which is consistent with the crystal structure. The room temperature moment of 5.14 μB is close to that expected for the weak-field ion with spin−orbit coupling (5.20 μB), with the slightly lower value indicative of the small perturbation from ideal octahedral geometry as is structurally observed.

High-spin octahedral CoII has a 4T1g ground state and, as a consequence, exhibits unquenched spin-orbit coupling in addition to zero-field splitting, which dominates at low temperature. Unfortunately, no expression accounts for both factors simultaneously. Therefore, the data for 2 were fit with eq 2 (with x = λ/k B T) for spin-orbit coupling, λ, of CoII, which dominates above 50 K (Figure ). The best fit is obtained with values of A = 1.5, k = 1.0, λ = -170 cm-1, and ν = 3, where A is a crystal field parameter (A = 1.5 is weak-field limit), k represents electron delocalization (k = 1.0 is minimal), λ is the spin-orbit coupling constant (λ = -176 cm-1 is the free-ion value), and ν describes the distorted geometrical configurations (ν is proportional to 1/λ). Thus, the fit suggests cobalt ions with slightly distorted octahedral geometry, which is consistent with the crystal structure. The room temperature moment of 5.14 μB is close to that expected for the weak-field ion with spin-orbit coupling (5.20 μB), with the slightly lower value indicative of the small perturbation from ideal octahedral geometry as is structurally observed.

elements.content: Temperature dependence of the effective moment, μeff(T), and reciprocal susceptibility, 1/χ(T), for 1 (◇), 2 (○), and 3 (□), and fit to eq 2 for 2, and Curie−Weiss equation and eq 3 for 3.
elements.clean_text: 3  Temperature dependence of the effective moment, μeff(T), and reciprocal susceptibility, 1/χ(T), for 1 (◇), 2 (○), and 3 (□), and fit to eq 2 for 2, and Curie-Weiss equation and eq 3 for 3.

elements.content:
<fig id="ic001379tf2" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label></label>
<graphic orientation="portrait" position="float" xlink:href="ic001379tf2.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

Similar behavior was observed for 1-D compound 1. However, the susceptibility is higher at low temperature than that of 2, and the data could not be fit to eq 2. The enhanced susceptibility of 1 with respect to 2 is attributed to a contribution from the interlayer coupling via the five-atom μ-[NCNCN]- linkages present in 1, but not 2. Since models presently cannot account for this coupling in addition to the effect arising from spin−orbit coupling, the data cannot be modeled. Because the octahedral geometry of the CoII ion is similar for both 1 and 2, their magnetic behavior should be similar. Hence, the less decreasing moment with decreasing temperature of 1 with respect to 2 suggests that their differences must be attributed to their 1- and 2-D structural motifs, 1 consisting of weakly interacting linear chains. The more rapidly decreasing moment of 2 at lower temperatures is in agreement with this hypothesis. At ∼13 K there is an upturn in the susceptibility for both 1 and 2. The origin of this is unknown; however, AC susceptibility measurements did not reveal a peak; hence, the increase is not due to magnetic ordering. Similar behavior was observed in the compound Co[C(CN)3]2.
elements.clean_text: Similar behavior was observed for 1-D compound 1. However, the susceptibility is higher at low temperature than that of 2, and the data could not be fit to eq 2. The enhanced susceptibility of 1 with respect to 2 is attributed to a contribution from the interlayer coupling via the five-atom μ-[NCNCN]- linkages present in 1, but not 2. Since models presently cannot account for this coupling in addition to the effect arising from spin-orbit coupling, the data cannot be modeled. Because the octahedral geometry of the CoII ion is similar for both 1 and 2, their magnetic behavior should be similar. Hence, the less decreasing moment with decreasing temperature of 1 with respect to 2 suggests that their differences must be attributed to their 1- and 2-D structural motifs, 1 consisting of weakly interacting linear chains. The more rapidly decreasing moment of 2 at lower temperatures is in agreement with this hypothesis. At ~13 K there is an upturn in the susceptibility for both 1 and 2. The origin of this is unknown; however, AC susceptibility measurements did not reveal a peak; hence, the increase is not due to magnetic ordering. Similar behavior was observed in the compound Co[C(CN)3]2.

elements.content: The χ(T) of 3 can be fit to the Curie−Weiss equation with g = 1.99(1) and θ = −3.04(4) K, Figure . The g value is within experimental error of the expected value of 2.00 for the isotropic MnII ion. The small θ value reflects a weak antiferromagnetic coupling between the MnII ions within the 2-D layers. At room temperature, the effective moment, μeff, has a value of 5.85 μB, which is slightly less than the expected spin-only value of 5.92 μB for paramagnetic S = 5/2 spins. Upon cooling, μeff(T) remains invariant until ∼50 K, where it then begins to decrease more rapidly owing to increasing antiferromagnetic correlations. A value of 3.47 μB is obtained at 2 K. At these low temperatures, a small zero-field splitting may also contribute, but it is often too small to be of any significance.
elements.clean_text: The χ(T) of 3 can be fit to the Curie-Weiss equation with g = 1.99(1) and θ = -3.04(4) K, Figure . The g value is within experimental error of the expected value of 2.00 for the isotropic MnII ion. The small θ value reflects a weak antiferromagnetic coupling between the MnII ions within the 2-D layers. At room temperature, the effective moment, μeff, has a value of 5.85 μB, which is slightly less than the expected spin-only value of 5.92 μB for paramagnetic S = 5/2 spins. Upon cooling, μeff(T) remains invariant until ~50 K, where it then begins to decrease more rapidly owing to increasing antiferromagnetic correlations. A  value of 3.47 μB is obtained at 2 K. At these low temperatures, a small zero-field splitting may also contribute, but it is often too small to be of any significance.

elements.content: The μeff(T) data for 3 were also fit to the 2-D Rushbrooke−Wood model (eq 3) in an effort to ascertain the magnitude of the exchange interaction, giving g = 1.99(1) and J/k B = −0.11(1) K, Figure . This small J value is comparable to that observed for the heteroleptic linear chain compounds Mn[N(CN)2]2(L)2 (L = methanol, N,N-dimethylformamide, pyridine) with J/ k B = −0.12 K. Moreover, the expected maximum, as is typical of a 2-D-layered system, was not observed and likely occurs at a lower temperature than could be measured. Similarly, long-range magnetic ordering was not observed above 2 K. The coupling is characteristic of weak antiferromagnetic interactions across the five-atom dicyanamide bridge.
elements.clean_text: The μeff(T) data for 3 were also fit to the 2-D Rushbrooke-Wood model (eq 3) in an effort to ascertain the magnitude of the exchange interaction, giving g = 1.99(1) and J/k B = -0.11(1) K, Figure . This small J value is comparable to that observed for the heteroleptic linear chain compounds Mn[N(CN)2]2(L)2 (L = methanol, N,N-dimethylformamide, pyridine) with J/ k B = -0.12 K.     Moreover, the expected maximum, as is typical of a 2-D-layered system, was not observed and likely occurs at a lower temperature than could be measured. Similarly, long-range magnetic ordering was not observed above 2 K. The coupling is characteristic of weak antiferromagnetic interactions across the five-atom dicyanamide bridge.

elements.content: In summary, three homoleptic dicyanamide compounds, namely, 1-D [Ph4P]2{Co[N(CN)2]4} and the 2-D [Ph4P]{M[N(CN)2]3} (M = Co, Mn), have been prepared. The structures contain only dicyanamide ligands that bridge through the nitrile nitrogen atoms. Stronger magnetic coupling that leads to magnetic ordering requires bonding via the central amide nitrogen, a motif absent in these compounds. Therefore the lack of low-temperature magnetic ordering is expected. We are currently investigating the solution properties of 2 to determine the stability and utility of the proposed soluble tetrahedral monomer.
elements.clean_text: In summary, three homoleptic dicyanamide compounds, namely, 1-D [Ph4P]2{Co[N(CN)2]4} and the 2-D [Ph4P]{M[N(CN)2]3} (M = Co, Mn), have been prepared. The structures contain only dicyanamide ligands that bridge through the nitrile nitrogen atoms. Stronger magnetic coupling that leads to magnetic ordering requires bonding via the central amide nitrogen, a motif absent in these compounds. Therefore the lack of low-temperature magnetic ordering is expected. We are currently investigating the solution properties of 2 to determine the stability and utility of the proposed soluble tetrahedral monomer.

cln_elements.content:
[Ph 4 P] 2 {Co[N(CN) 2 ] 4 } (1). A solution of 0.35 g (1.2 mmol) of Co(NO3)2·6H2O dissolved in 30 mL of acetone was added to a stirred solution of 0.25 g (2.4 mmol) of K[N(CN)2] and 0.97 g (2.4 mmol) of (Ph4P)[N(CN)2] in 120 mL of acetone. The resulting dark blue solution was stirred for 5 min and then filtered. The filtrate was reduced to 30 mL, and ether diffusion produced a mixture of white and pink needles. The mixture was washed with 95% ethanol to remove the white crystals and produce 180 mg (15%) of homogeneous pink needles.

[Ph 4 P]{Co[N(CN) 2 ] 3 } (2). A solution of 0.30 g (1.0 mmol) of Co(NO3)2·6H2O dissolved in 30 mL of acetone was added to a stirred solution of 0.22 g (2.0 mmol) of K[N(CN)2] and 0.42 g (1.0 mmol) of (Ph4P)[N(CN)2] in 120 mL of acetone. The resulting dark blue solution was stirred for 1 h and then filtered. The filtrate was reduced to 20 mL, and ether diffusion produced 75 mg (10%) of pink block crystals.

[Ph 4 P]{Mn[N(CN) 2 ] 3 } (3). A solution of 0.186 g (0.94 mmol) of MnCl2·4H2O in 10 mL of ethanol was slowly added to a solution of 0.800 g (1.97 mmol) of [Ph4P][N(CN)2] in 10 mL of CH2Cl2 to give a colorless solution. The reaction mixture was allowed to slowly evaporate at room temperature for 3 days, at which time large colorless blocks of [Ph4P]{Mn[N(CN)2]3} had grown. The crystals were collected via vacuum filtration and air-dried to give 0.249 g (45%) of colorless block crystals.

[Ph  4  P]  2  {Co[N(CN)  2  ]  4  } (1). A solution of 0.35 g (1.2 mmol) of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O dissolved in 30 mL of acetone was added to a stirred solution of 0.25 g (2.4 mmol) of K[N(CN)2] and 0.97 g (2.4 mmol) of (Ph4P)[N(CN)2] in 120 mL of acetone. The resulting dark blue solution was stirred for 5 min and then filtered. The filtrate was reduced to 30 mL, and ether diffusion produced a mixture of white and pink needles. The mixture was washed with 95% ethanol to remove the white crystals and produce 180 mg (15%) of homogeneous pink needles. 

 [Ph  4  P]{Co[N(CN)  2  ]  3  } (2). A solution of 0.30 g (1.0 mmol) of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O dissolved in 30 mL of acetone was added to a stirred solution of 0.22 g (2.0 mmol) of K[N(CN)2] and 0.42 g (1.0 mmol) of (Ph4P)[N(CN)2] in 120 mL of acetone. The resulting dark blue solution was stirred for 1 h and then filtered. The filtrate was reduced to 20 mL, and ether diffusion produced 75 mg (10%) of pink block crystals. 

 [Ph  4  P]{Mn[N(CN)  2  ]  3  } (3). A solution of 0.186 g (0.94 mmol) of MnCl2⋅4H2O in 10 mL of ethanol was slowly added to a solution of 0.800 g (1.97 mmol) of [Ph4P][N(CN)2] in 10 mL of CH2Cl2 to give a colorless solution. The reaction mixture was allowed to slowly evaporate  at room temperature for 3 days, at which time large colorless blocks of [Ph4P]{Mn[N(CN)2]3} had grown. The crystals were collected via vacuum filtration and air-dried to give 0.249 g (45%) of colorless block crystals.
